data.title: Pausing scene
data.body:
Pausing the scene and then resuming the scene causes the pause button to not work again. 

The code that i am using is from the pause demo.
func _ready():
    # Initialization here
    connect("pressed",self,"on_pauseButton_pressed")

func on_pauseButton_pressed():
    get_parent().get_node("PopupMenu").set_exclusive(true)
    get_parent().get_node("PopupMenu").popup()
    get_tree().set_pause(true)

and this is the code to go back to the scene.

func _process(delta):
    if(get_node("levelselect").is_pressed()):
        get_tree().set_pause(false)
        get_node("/root/global").goto_scene("res://Assets/scenes/levelSelector.scn")
    if(get_node("resume").is_pressed()):
        get_tree().set_pause(false)
        hide()
    if(get_node("restart").is_pressed()):
        get_tree().set_pause(false)
        get_node("/root/global").goto_scene("res://Assets/levels/level_1.scn")

If i restart or go back to level select the button works fine. The problem is only when resuming the game.

data.title: External resources and subresources are not sorted logically in 2.0 format
data.body:
Here is an example of git diff output when converting a 1.1 scene to the 2.0 format:

```
-<resource_file type="PackedScene" subresource_count="11" version="1.1" version_name="Godot Engine v1.1.stable.custom_build">
-       <ext_resource path="res://scripts/menu.gd" type="Script"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://background.png" type="Texture"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://fonts/firasans-book-32.fnt" type="Font"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://fonts/firasans-book-16.fnt" type="Font"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://scripts/controls.gd" type="Script"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-up.png" type="Texture"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-down.png" type="Texture"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-left.png" type="Texture"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-right.png" type="Texture"></ext_resource>
-       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/pickups/bomb_increase.png" type="Texture"></ext_resource>
+<resource_file type="PackedScene" subresource_count="11" version="2.0" version_name="Godot Engine v2.0.alpha.custom_build">
+       <ext_resource path="res://scripts/menu.gd" type="Script" index="0"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-down.png" type="Texture" index="6"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://background.png" type="Texture" index="1"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://fonts/firasans-book-32.fnt" type="Font" index="2"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://fonts/firasans-book-16.fnt" type="Font" index="3"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://scripts/controls.gd" type="Script" index="4"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-right.png" type="Texture" index="8"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-up.png" type="Texture" index="5"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/icons/arrow-left.png" type="Texture" index="7"></ext_resource>
+       <ext_resource path="res://sprites/pickups/bomb_increase.png" type="Texture" index="9"></ext_resource>
```

The ext_resource index seems to be well computed, and I guess the XML scene header should list ext_resource sorted by their index too. The current order does not seem really logical.

data.title: [Feature Request] Possibility to create scenes with root node from external file
data.body:
It's impossible to have node from external file as a root node. In our game we use couple of hacks to bypass that limitation but they create another problems and are generally troublesome. 
Why I think there should be this possibility? Because it's easier to do hierarchical objects structure thanks to this, (just like in object oriented programming, but with scenes). **Maybe I will give real life example here.**

Let's say we will have enemies in our game, quite a lot of them most of them very similar to each other. We could create one scene "BaseEnemy" write a script there, add a lot of inner nodes that are needed for this code to work and setup nice amount of export variables (thanks to them we will be able to modify individual enemies behaviour):
![baseenemy](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/9976058/4cb2e910-5ed5-11e5-9918-d482628fa555.png)
_A base enemy scene_

Then for each concrete enemy we cloud just simply load BaseEnemy as root node, setup exported values of Enemy and decorate it with additional specific nodes that are needed like model asset, or additional weapon. 
![concreteenemy](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/9976059/516670c6-5ed5-11e5-9250-903b202b4499.png)
_A concrete enemy scene_

Now when we need to change some shared node/logic of our enemy in some way, we don't need to update 10 files separately, we only need to update that single "BaseEnemy.xscn" one :) 

I think that this simple feature would make life of at least some of us a lot easier :) What do you think? 
(Off course I mean "simple" from user side, not sure if this feature would not force another scene format change, but hey! They have changed already between current and 1.1 so it could be good time for this :)

**OS:** linux(archlinux)
**godot version:** 1.1-stable and 2.0-alpha-r1660.889d21e

Firstly, I'm not a native speaker of English , So I'm sorry if my English is hard to understand. 

I know that the IME on linux is not supported yet.
So I tried to copy and paste japanese word `テスト`(which means `test`) to Label , Button , Script editor , etc.
But both versions of godot display it as `\u30c6\u30b9\u30c8`.

I read some forum and issuie, and imported the font for everyday use.
Then godot uses the specified font for Latin characters.
But, CJK characters are not yet displayed properly.

data.title: dict2inst return an empty instance
data.body:
Say you create a dictionary from an instance using `inst2dict`. Then you want to recover the instance with the values inside already defined with `dict2inst`. You're happy it worked until you find out the recovered instance has **default** values and not the ones you defined earlier.

Here's a sample:

**object.gd:**

``` GDScript
var a = 0 setget set_a,get_a
var b = 2 setget set_b,get_b

func get_a():
    return a
func set_a(v):
    a = v
func get_b():
    return b
func set_b(v):
    b = v
```

**main.gd:**

``` GDScript
var objclass = preload("res://object.gd")

func _ready():
    var obj = objclass.new()
    obj.a = 5
    obj.b = 7

    print("orig a ", obj.a) # prints 5
    print("orig b ", obj.b) # prints 7

    var dictVal = inst2dict(obj)

    print("dict a ", dictVal.a) # prints 5
    print("dict b ", dictVal.b) # prints 7

    var instVal = dict2inst(dictVal)

    print("inst a ", instVal.a) # prints 0
    print("inst b ", instVal.b) # prints 2
```

data.title: Remove of use_exclude_ctrl_bones option
data.body:
use_exclude_ctrl_bones option is not implemented.
This option is supposed to filter-out unneeded skeleton bones.
This option was never implemented (in repository) and confuses
users that feature exists.
This commit removes this option as this option implementation
is not happenning any time soon and claim it exists
confuses users into thinking the feature is supported.

Closes #2476

data.title: CanvasItem.draw_set_transform() not limited to draw calls after transform is set.
data.body:
I'm trying to use the CanvasItem.draw\* methods to render a mask into a render target viewport. I need to draw textures on the mask using different transforms for each texture. draw_set_transform() says:

_Set a custom transform for drawing. Anything drawn afterwards will be transformed by this._

I interpret that to mean anything drawn _before_ draw_set_transform() would not have the transform applied (or would use whatever was last passed to a draw_set_transform() call).  However the behavior I see in 1.1stable is that everything in the _draw() call is rendered using the transform. My draw method code:

```
func _draw():
    draw_circle(Vector2(100,100), 30, Color(1, 0, 0))
    # BUG??? this causes the circle to be transformed as well.  Uncommenting the last line
    # causes no transformation to the texture or circle.
    draw_set_transform(Vector2(50,10), 0, Vector2(1,1))
    draw_texture(texture, Vector2(10,10))
#   draw_set_transform(Vector2(10,50), 0, Vector2(1,1)) 
```

Both the circle and the texture are drawn with the draw_set_transform() applied. Similarly, if I uncomment the last line, neither the circle or texture are placed using the first draw_set_transform() applied. It behaves as though whatever was last passed to draw_set_transform() is used for all the draw_\* calls.

With both transform calls commented out (the drawn texture is the Documentation text box):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4614207/9944446/5e4075ac-5d55-11e5-80d4-bc59fed684b0.png)

With just the first transform call uncommented:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4614207/9944459/790ba51e-5d55-11e5-814b-117f3a2b08fc.png)

With both calls uncommented:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4614207/9944472/898d86aa-5d55-11e5-97da-9984604ac8a8.png)

Is this expected behavior???    If so the doc should be clarified.  Is there any other way to _individually_ orient the textures I want to draw with draw_texture?  

I can send a small project that replicates the problem but here is most of it:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4614207/9944504/b520eaf0-5d55-11e5-839b-a532e112f052.png)

data.title: exporter bone filter option is not implemented
data.body:
Exporter bone filter option is not implemented. it is present in list of options,
you can check/uncheck it but it doesn't do anything.

The option name is use_exclude_ctrl_bones

This options hsould either be removed to reduce confusion (easier)
or should be implemented (harder). Probably there is some version of exporter script with that
implemented, but probability is low. Or there is merge error (unlikely).

This option is in exporter script from the start and it was never implemented.
So for cleanness sake this should be removed.

This is another example of how often the exporter script is used (and
how often the bone system is used, among everything in 3D portion of the engine).

Actually the approach of selecting bones by name is not really good as one could check
of the bone is modifier bone and ignore it if it is not. Now script imports all bones being useful or not,
which leads to messed-up bone system if complicated rigs are used with many mechanism bones
(quite common case with Blender if Rigify is used or clothes rig is needed).

data.title: Unable to compile server export template
Fix android build script
data.body:
some fixes for android build script.
remove "armv6","x86" options and add "android_arch" option for select compiler architecture (armv7,armv6,x86)(default armv7).
add architecture suffix for output files and you can compile for several architecture simultaneously.
example:
libgodot.android.opt.debug.armv7.so
libgodot.android.opt.debug.armv7.neon.so
libgodot.android.opt.debug.armv6.so
libgodot.android.opt.debug.x86.so
now we can enable/disable neon on armv7 with "android_neon" option (default enable).
add "NDK_TARGET_X86" option for select toolchain to use for the NDK x86 (default x86-4.8).
change inputs model for "ndk_platform" option (default android-15).
fix armv7 ccflags.
with this patch, must put libgodot_android.so file in specific architecture folder:
armv7 (default): [android-java]/libs/armeabi-v7a/
armv6: [android-java]/libs/armeabi/
x86: [android-java]/libs/x86/

libgodot_android.so before:
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9015847/9904071/6b34119e-5c90-11e5-8889-8ca0fc318444.png)
libgodot_android.so after:
![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9015847/9904079/78027e7e-5c90-11e5-9f87-d2cd28bbb08e.png)

after apply this patch, i run "Isometric 2D + Lighting" on my galaxy note 3 and the result is very faster from before.

data.title: Shader Editor usability issue due to Visual Editor's focus on hover
data.body:
I recently started to work with shaders and there was a problem that is annoying me a lot:

The canvas and spatial visual editors will always get focus on mouse hover. Since the shader editor is in the same screen (both split), I constantly lose the focus when writing shaders without even noticing it and then I am forced to manually focus it again (when I never intended to lose the focus).

It would be good to have an option to disable this behaviour (visual editor focus on mouse hover).

data.title: Problem with Particles2D Starting On By Default?
data.body:
![output](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/531175/9871615/69750caa-5b5a-11e5-8d5f-835f07b3fe14.gif)

I think there's some sort of problem with Particles2D starting ON by default.  Consider the following minimal test case:

```
extends Node2D

func _ready():
    var newParticle = Particles2D.new()
    newParticle.set_pos(Vector2(200, 200))
    newParticle.set_scale(Vector2(5, 5)) #make it easier to see

    newParticle.set_explosiveness(0)
    #newParticle.set_emit_timeout(2) #this is also the default lifetime

    add_child(newParticle)
```

Here are the three conditions:

1) Initial code, particles appear

2) Uncomment line 10, particles disappear

3) Change explosiveness on line 9 to 0.1, particles appear again

data.title: Drag and drop reparenting
data.body: Not sure if this has already been requested. It would be cool to be able to drag and drop one node, multiple nodes, or a group of nodes into another node for re-parenting instead of clicking the re-parent button to re-parent nodes.

It worked on the 1.1.

data.title: Set AnimationEditor UndoRedo reference on creation, Fix #2418
data.body: Resolve the problem where the animation editor crash the editor when trying to rename, duplicate or delete an animation (#2418).

data.title: Set particles in state based on time
data.body: Right now you can set the lifetime of a Particles2D object and it will run for that amount of seconds.  However, in GDScript, there is no way to reset that timer back to the beginning or to an arbitrary time in the animation phase.  You have to wait for it to reach the lifetime and finish the animation.  This means if you want to change the parameters and options of an existing Particles2D object, you will get inconsistent results based on where it was in the previous state of animation.  Being able to set the time (or at least restart it) would be helpful.
